paragraphs.text:
%md # Introduction to Splice Machine Developer Training, Part I This class is recommended for query writers, ETL processors, and developers who are working with Splice Machine. To understand this content, you need to have experience with: * using SQL * programming with Python or Scala You can expect to spend 1-2 hours completing this *Splice Machine Developer Training, Part I* class, which contains the following sequence of notebooks:
1. If you've not already done so, please visit our Splice Machine Basics notebook for an overview of Splice Machine before diving into this set of notebooks.
2. And if you're new to using Zeppelin, our Zeppelin Notebook Basics notebook is a brief introduction to running and creating/modifying Zeppelin notebooks, which you'll need to know before proceeding with the other notebooks in this section.
3. This class starts with our Preparing Data for Import notebook, which helps you understand how to prepare data that you want to import into your Splice Machine database.
4. The Importing Data into Your Database notebook walks you through importing data into your Splice Machine database from flat files that are stored in S3.
5. The Running Queries notebook introduces you to querying your Splice Machine database.
6. The Tuning Queries for Performance notebook introduces a number of tips you can employ to help generate the lowest cost plan and best performance for your queries, including: collecting statistics, compacting, creating primary keys and indexes, and strategies for joining tables.
7. The Using the Database Console notebook introduces the dashboard you can use to monitor queries sent to the Spark engine; this allows you to follow the progress of queries running in Spark, monitor GC usage, and terminate queries when necessary.
8. The Explaining and Hinting notebook teaches you how to understand query execution plans and how to use hints to influence execution plans.
9. The Exercises for This Class notebook contains a number of exercises that you should complete to test your understanding of the content in this class.
Note that each notebook contains a link to the next notebook in the sequence, and many of the notebooks also contain links to related pages in our Splice Machine Documentation web.

msg.data:
Introduction to Splice Machine Developer Training, Part I

This class is recommended for query writers, ETL processors, and developers who are working with Splice Machine. To understand this content, you need to have experience with:

  • using SQL
  • programming with Python or Scala

You can expect to spend 1-2 hours completing this Splice Machine Developer Training, Part I class, which contains the following sequence of notebooks:

1. If you've not already done so, please visit our Splice Machine Basics notebook for an overview of Splice Machine before diving into this set of notebooks.
2. And if you're new to using Zeppelin, our Zeppelin Notebook Basics notebook is a brief introduction to running and creating/modifying Zeppelin notebooks, which you'll need to know before proceeding with the other notebooks in this section.
3. This class starts with our Preparing Data for Import notebook, which helps you understand how to prepare data that you want to import into your Splice Machine database.
4. The Importing Data into Your Database notebook walks you through importing data into your Splice Machine database from flat files that are stored in S3.
5. The Running Queries notebook introduces you to querying your Splice Machine database.
6. The Tuning Queries for Performance notebook introduces a number of tips you can employ to help generate the lowest cost plan and best performance for your queries, including: collecting statistics, compacting, creating primary keys and indexes, and strategies for joining tables.
7. The Using the Database Console notebook introduces the dashboard you can use to monitor queries sent to the Spark engine; this allows you to follow the progress of queries running in Spark, monitor GC usage, and terminate queries when necessary.
8. The Explaining and Hinting notebook teaches you how to understand query execution plans and how to use hints to influence execution plans.
9. The Exercises for This Class notebook contains a number of exercises that you should complete to test your understanding of the content in this class.

Note that each notebook contains a link to the next notebook in the sequence, and many of the notebooks also contain links to related pages in our Splice Machine Documentation web.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Where to Go Next
Please start this class with the [*Preparing Data for Import*](/#/notebook/2DX8XQH89) notebook for a brief introduction to preparing the data you want to import into your database.
